channel.title: Party Hat Model
channel.description:
[center]First of all this was made in C4D[/center] This is just my party hat that I made, this took me roughly 2 hours. Each picture is the same model, just with a different texture. And[b] I KNOW[/b] this really is not that great and there is a few spots I couldnt fix, but I thought id give modeling a party hat a try since i have not seen one thread yet :)
[IMG]http://i43.tinypic.com/f372up.png[/img] [IMG]http://i40.tinypic.com/koi6t.png[/img] [IMG]http://i41.tinypic.com/1zwyw75.png[/img] [IMG]http://i44.tinypic.com/o8ck5y.png[/img] [IMG]http://i40.tinypic.com/22xnx5.png[/img] [IMG]http://i40.tinypic.com/103z7nb.png[/img] [IMG]http://i44.tinypic.com/35l7ltd.png[/img]

item.title: Party Hat Model
item.dc:creator: @ravens ravens
item.description:
@ravens wrote:

[quote=“Butchd12, post:16, topic:433897”][quote author=reyx7 link=topic=536613.msg3924754#msg3924754 date=1330114991]
I see this on a number of them.

x1r5.png705×552

[/quote]

so? I already said its not perfect[/quote]
its not just minor flaws, it indicates you may have modeled this object completely incorrectly

it seems you did each one of the triangular parts individually, which is not recommended unless they are supposed to look different, and the fact that it appears to be overlapping or missing faces is pretty strange considering its such a simple model

heres how i would do it, im not sure if this is possible in your program but the main idea might be the same

start with a circle, extrude, scale down a little along the x and y axis (east and west), extrude up along z axis (north), pull up the parts which are suppose to stick up further up along the z axis, and your done… not very hard

im not saying there is only one way to do it, this is just one example

Read full topic

item.title: Party Hat Model
item.dc:creator: @dylan_0789 dylan_0789
item.description:
@dylan_0789 wrote:

[quote=“Butchd12, post:10, topic:433897”][quote author=reyx7 link=topic=536613.msg3923525#msg3923525 date=1329959945]
How did these take 2 hours each? It’s just a cylinder cut up with a texture on it… and the light refracts on them rather oddly.
[/quote]

There is much more then just that to get the points, but yeah, i just took a cylinder and a few rectangles and put them in a certain boole and made the points that way, i might post alot of my other work soon… ( I want to make some more)

How did these take 2 hours each? It’s just a cylinder cut up with a texture on it… and the light refracts on them rather oddly.

Two hours probably means including the time spent messing around to get a “feel” for the program.

OT: The model itself is fairly good from what I can see, although the purple has an odd transparency to it. And for a RS model, having the thin extrusion for a thickness is not necessary, it will not show ingame.

And I never had to get a “feel” for the program, I took a 3D Modeling and Animation class last year in my junior year in highschool… and i just ran into a few problems that I couldnt fiquare out how to fix, sorry Im not perfect

Oh, and they are all just ONE model if you didnt see that part.

Are those textures or materials? Wonderful job for the most part, anyways. Can’t wait to see some more.

Textures/materials… Arent they really just the same thing? And do you have any suggestions? I cant really do a sword yet, but I am trying to learn how :)[/quote]
Textures and materials are nowhere near the same. Materials are actually used for shading, not necessarily to color the model(or at least not anymore). Textures are used to ‘project’ an image onto a model. Think of Materials as the shading method(or how light reacts with the model) to the model (hence blinn, lambert, phong, anisotropic…) , and the texture as the detail or image projection. If you took modeling and animation, your teacher should have taught you that…

And you definitely can make a sword. Getting into the mind state that you are unable to model something is like taking a step back in modeling. You always want to push yourself whether it be in the structure, design, texture detail, etc. Just keep pushing, you will learn more from a failed but hard worked attempt at a car(for example), than you will making a sword. Planning is also key. Know what you want to do before you start or your wire frame will be horrendous.

Read full topic
